snippet: After a sheriffs association sought to ban unconcealed weapons, fearing they might frighten voters, the state’s attorney general ruled that guns could be openly displayed at polling sites.
abstract: Alabama is focus of controversy over open-carry gun laws after state Attorney General Luther Strange ruled that local jurisdictions did not have the right to block voters from carrying weapons to their poling places; bans had been put in place by the state Sheriffs Association, which feared that guns might frighten voters.
lead_paragraph: After a sheriffs association sought to ban unconcealed weapons, fearing they might frighten voters, the state’s attorney general ruled that guns could be openly displayed at polling sites.

headline.main: Alabama Ruling Hobbles Ban on Guns in the Open at Polls
headline.print_headline: Alabama Ruling Hobbles Ban on Guns in the Open at Polls
